To prove this equivalence, observe that if $f$ has a root in $K$, then $K \cong K[X] / (X - x_0)$ is a homomorphic image of $K[X] / (f)$ and therefore $(K[X] / (f), K) \not\models \psi_{K,n}$ since $(K, K) \not\models \psi_{K,n}$. Also, clearly $f$ cannot be factored as a product of two polynomials without roots. This proves the implication $\Longleftarrow$.
For the other direction, assume that $f$ does not have a root in $K$. If $f$ is irreducible, $K[X] / (f)$ is a number field of degree $n$ over $K$ and therefore satisfies $\psi_{K,n}$. If $f$ is not irreducible, it can be factored as a product of polynomials of smaller degree which have no root in $K$.
Using induction on $n$, the criterion can be phrased existentially in terms of the coefficients of $f$. This proves the first statement.

To prove this equivalence, observe that if $f$ has a root in $K$, then $K \cong K[X] / (X - x_0)$ is a homomorphic image of $K[X] / (f)$ and therefore $(K[X] / (f), K) \not\models \psi_{K,n}$ since $(K, K) \not\models \psi_{K,n}$. Also, clearly $f$ cannot be factored as a product of two polynomials without roots. This proves the implication $\Longleftarrow$.
For the other direction, assume that $f$ does not have a root in $K$. If $f$ is irreducible, $K[X] / (f)$ is a number field of degree $n$ over $K$ and therefore satisfies $\psi_{K,n}$. If $f$ is not irreducible, it can be factored as a product of polynomials of smaller degree which have no root in $K$.
Using induction on $n$, the criterion can be phrased existentially in terms of the coefficients of $f$. This proves the first statement.
